snippet.title: Donald Trump: China defends itself against US President criticism over North Korea
snippet.content:
China has hit back after US President Donald Trump tweeted he was "very disappointed" in China following Pyongyang's latest missile test.
Key points:
China was responding to tweets sent by Mr Trump on Saturday China has previously denounced US sanctions on North Korea as unhelpful Mr Trump spoke about North Korea via phone with Japan's Prime Minister
In a statement responding to Mr Trump's tweets, China's Foreign Ministry said the North Korean nuclear issue did not arise because of China and that everyone needed to work together to seek a resolution. "All parties should have a correct understanding of this," it said, adding the international community widely recognised China's efforts to seek a resolution. that it said proved its ability to strike the US mainland, drawing a sharp warning from Mr Trump and a rebuke from China. Ms Haley added that any new UN Security Council resolution "that does not significantly increase the international pressure on North Korea is of no value", adding that Japan and South Korea also needed to do more. A White House statement after the phone call between the US and Japanese leaders "agreed that North Korea poses a grave and growing direct threat to the United States, Japan, the Republic of Korea, and other countries near and far". It said Mr Trump "reaffirmed our ironclad commitment" to defend Japan and South Korea from any attack, "using the full range of United States capabilities".
Photo:(AP: Eugene Hoshiko, file) Mr Abe told reporters after his conversation with Mr Trump that the two countries would take steps towards concrete action but did not give details. "International society, including Russia and China, need to take this seriously and increase pressure," Mr Abe said. Mr Abe and Mr Trump did not discuss military action against North Korea, nor what would constitute the crossing of a "red line" by Pyongyang, Deputy Chief Cabinet spokesman Koichi Hagiuda said. The Russian Foreign Ministry said in a statement that the United States and other countries were trying "to shift responsibility for the situation to Russia and China" and that such attempts were baseless. Disappointed in China's approach
Photo:(AP: Ahn Young-joon, file) Mr Trump and that Beijing profited from US trade but had done "nothing" for the United States with regards to North Korea. He wrote that he would not allow this situation to continue. Chinese Vice Commerce Minister Qian Keming also responded to Mr Trump's comments, telling a news conference there was no link between the North Korea issue and China-US trade. "We think the North Korea nuclear issue and China-US trade are issues that are in two completely different domains," he said. "They aren't related. They should not be discussed together." China - North Korea's major trade partner - has repeatedly said it strictly follows UN resolutions on North Korea and has denounced unilateral US sanctions as unhelpful. Beijing wants both balanced trade with the United States and lasting peace on the Korean peninsula, its official Xinhua news agency added in a commentary. "However, to realise these goals, Beijing needs a more cooperative partner in the White House, not one who piles blame on China for the United States' failures," it added.
